Enhance the capacity of the country’s mangrove and seagrass
ecosystems to act as a carbon sink by 2030, through increased
protection of mangroves and by removing a cumulative total of
381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.
column11: TOPIC: "Management of marine, fisheries and coastal zones" KEYWORDS: "coastal zone risk retention - soft structure, coastal zone risk retention - hard structure, coastal environment monitoring and risk assessment / prediction, disease management of marine resources, marine production promotion, marine ecosystem service management, marine fisheries and coastal zones education and consulting"

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Build on the mitigation target of expanding the current 12,827
hectares of mangroves under protection by at least a further 6,000
hectares of mangroves by 2025. The adaptation measure includes:
the establishment of new and/or improvement of existing public
conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly owned areas
identified in the Government’s mangrove priority areas from the
Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations 2018; partnerships
with landlords of privately owned mangroves, local communities,

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Build on the mitigation target of expanding the current 12,827
hectares of mangroves under protection by at least a further 6,000
hectares of mangroves by 2025. The adaptation measure includes:
the establishment of new and/or improvement of existing public
conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly owned areas
identified in the Government’s mangrove priority areas from the
Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations 2018; partnerships
with landlords of privately owned mangroves, local communities,
bilateral and multilateral agencies; and the continued enforcement
of the 2018 mangrove regulations.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

restoration.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly owned areas

of the 2018 mangrove regulations.

column6:
Enhance the capacity of the country’s mangrove and seagrass
ecosystems to act as a carbon sink by 2030, through increased
protection of mangroves and by removing a cumulative total of
381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.
column11: TOPIC: "Sustainable forest management" KEYWORDS: " Natural forest management,  Improved plantations,  Forest fire management"
column12: #Yes. #1. TOPIC: The NDC Target Text mentions the topic of "Sustainable forest management" by discussing the enhancement of mangrove and seagrass ecosystems as a carbon sink. #2. KEYWORDS: The NDC Target Text includes the following keywords: mangrove restoration.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.
column11: TOPIC: "Sustainable forest management" KEYWORDS: " Natural forest management,  Improved plantations,  Forest fire management"

column6:

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Build on the mitigation target of expanding the current 12,827
hectares of mangroves under protection by at least a further 6,000
hectares of mangroves by 2025. The adaptation measure includes:
the establishment of new and/or improvement of existing public
conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly owned areas
identified in the Government’s mangrove priority areas from the
Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations 2018; partnerships
with landlords of privately owned mangroves, local communities,
bilateral and multilateral agencies; and the continued enforcement
of the 2018 mangrove regulations.

column6:
Enhance the capacity of the country’s mangrove and seagrass
ecosystems to act as a carbon sink by 2030, through increased
protection of mangroves and by removing a cumulative total of
381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.
column11: TOPIC: "Sustainable management of freshwater and wetlands: KEYWORDS:  wetland management, sustainable freshwater management

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.
column11: TOPIC: "Sustainable management of freshwater and wetlands: KEYWORDS:  wetland management, sustainable freshwater management
column12: #Yes. #1. TOPIC: The NDC Target Text mentions the sustainable management of wetlands, specifically mangroves. #2. KEYWORDS: The NDC Target Text includes the keyword "wetland management" and "sustainable freshwater management".

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.
column11: TOPIC: "Sustainable management of marine and coastal zones" KEYWORDS:  "mangrove management, coastal management, tidal salt marshes"

restoration.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.
column11: TOPIC: "Restoration of marine and coastal zones" KEYWORDS:  "restore marine ecosystems, Coastal wetland restoration, Restore degraded mangroves, seagrass beds reefs, Restore mangroves for carbon sequestration, Mangrove restoration, Seaforestation, coastal restoration, Seagrass restoration, coral reef restoration"

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.
column11: TOPIC: "Restoration of marine and coastal zones" KEYWORDS:  "restore marine ecosystems, Coastal wetland restoration, Restore degraded mangroves, seagrass beds reefs, Restore mangroves for carbon sequestration, Mangrove restoration, Seaforestation, coastal restoration, Seagrass restoration, coral reef restoration"

381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Enhance the capacity of the country’s mangrove and seagrass
ecosystems to act as a carbon sink by 2030, through increased
protection of mangroves and by removing a cumulative total of
381 KtCO2e between 2021 and 2030 through mangrove
restoration.
column11: TOPIC: "Miscillaneous ecosystem and wildlife natue-based actions" KEYWORDS: "ecosystem protection, ecosystem restoration,  wildlife corridors, Restore pollinator habitat, rewilding, Restore degraded habitats, other effective conservation measures (OECM), Increase connectivity between protected areas, Create community reserves, prevent species extintion, reduce threatened species, restricting invasive species"

column6:
Building on the 12,827 hectares of mangroves currently under
protection, protect at least a further 6,000 hectares of
mangroves by 2025, with an additional 6,000 hectares by 2030.
This includes the establishment of new and/or improvement of
existing public conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly
owned areas identified in the Government’s mangrove priority
areas from the Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations
2018; partnerships with landlords of privately owned
mangroves, local communities, bilateral and multilateral
agencies and the continued enforcement of the 2018 mangrove
regulations. This is a non-CO2e commitment, since baseline
mangrove loss has been negligible over the 20-year period from
2001 to 2020.

column6:
Build on the mitigation target of expanding the current 12,827
hectares of mangroves under protection by at least a further 6,000
hectares of mangroves by 2025. The adaptation measure includes:
the establishment of new and/or improvement of existing public
conservation measures to cover 100% of publicly owned areas
identified in the Government’s mangrove priority areas from the
Forests (Protection of Mangroves) Regulations 2018; partnerships
with landlords of privately owned mangroves, local communities,
bilateral and multilateral agencies; and the continued enforcement
of the 2018 mangrove regulations.
